article_text:
WASHINGTON—American consumers increased their spending in September amid strong auto sales, but slowing job growth and overseas turbulence has curbed some discretionary spending.

Retail sales rose a seasonally adjusted 0.1% in September from August, the Commerce Department said Wednesday. Economists had expected a rise in September of 0.2%. The...

og.description: American consumers increased their spending in September amid strong auto sales, but slowing job growth and overseas turbulence has curbed some discretionary spending.
og.title: Retail Sales Figures Mostly Disappoint

article_metadata.article.origheadline: U.S. Retail Sales Rose 0.1% in September

article_summary:
Retail sales rose a seasonally adjusted 0.1% in September from August, the Commerce Department said Wednesday.
WASHINGTON—American consumers increased their spending in September amid strong auto sales, but slowing job growth and overseas turbulence has curbed some discretionary spending.
Economists had expected a rise in September of 0.2%.
